issue: Pizza Hut was found guilty of paying delivery drivers below minimum wage.

An E. coli outbreak in one location infected over 200 people.

A boycott was organized against Rockstar due to the CEO and CFO's relationships with Michael Savage, a radio host banned from the UK due to his homophobic views.

Unilever filed a lawsuit against JUST, Inc for false advertising, claiming that they couldn't call their vegan "Just Mayo" product mayonnaise. The suit was dropped less than 2 months later.
I'm going to kill Baby Nut.
Founder David Portnoy joked that some people "deserve to be raped," dismissed criticism of this joke, and refused to apologize.

Founder David Portnoy threatened to fire Barstool employees if they tried to unionize and would "smash" any unionization attempts. He settled with the National Labor Relations Board by deleting the threatening tweets and getting rid of anti-union material.

After being accused of stealing a comedian's video and sharing it on their social media, Barstool fought against the accusation and later deleted thousands of their social media posts to avoid DMCA takedowns for other stolen content.

Founder David Portnoy has a history of making racist comments, many directed at Colin Kaepernick, all of which he refuses to apologize for, and has doubled down and claimed that he is "uncancellable."
Actor Anthony Mackie has spoken about Marvel's lack of Black representation behind the scenes, outside of Black Panther.
Disney has stopped daycare centers from painting trademarked characters like Mickey Mouse on their walls.

Amazon withheld information about COVID-19 test results in a Minnesota fulfillment center, leading to many infected workers staying at work.

Several employees and former employees of Riot Games spoke out about the sexism they experienced working there.
Employees have spoken out about sexism, sexual harassment, misgendering, and other abusive comments.
COO of Riot Games, Scott Gelb, was placed on unpaid leave for two months after it was alleged that he sexually harassed multiple employees.
A lawsuit against Riot Games regarding their gender discrimination and sexual harassment was settled for at least 10 million $USD.

Amazon emitted 44.4 million metric tons of carbon dioxide in 2018.

Amazon tracks and monitors Whole Foods stores they consider at risk of unionizing.
Amazon fired an employee who organized a protest against their lack of COVID-19 protections.

Workers in at least one warehouse had to work in 38¬∫C (100¬∫F) heat and suffered from dehydration. Amazon's initial response to this was to have an ambulance wait outside the warehouse to carry away sick employees.
In response to criticisms that workers were not paid livable wages, Amazon's minimum wage in the US and UK was raised to 15 $USD, at the expense of losing their bonuses and stock awards.
Amazon employees were told to work overtime during the COVID-19 outbreak as governments were instructing companies to limit social contact.
Amazon has secured several contracts with the CIA, posing a potential conflict-of-interest with Jeff Bezos' newspaper The Washington Post and their coverage of the CIA.

Amazon is facing antitrust charges from the European Union due to their treatment of third-party sellers.
Amazon started warning users that a third-party plugin that automatically applies coupons is a security risk after it was purchased by PayPal.
Amazon partnered with Apple to allow only authorized Apple products to be sold on Amazon, which has been criticized by smaller resellers and prompted an FTC investigation.
Delivery drivers suffer poor working conditions such as lack of overtime pay and time constraints that require them to skip meals and breaks.

Several news stations across the US all aired identically worded segments praising Amazon's response to the COVID-19 pandemic without clarifying that they had received their scripts from Amazon's PR department.
In India, Maggi brand noodles were again found to have lead in them.

A woman suffered third degree burns on her legs and genitals from spilling hot coffee on herself while in a parked car, with her surgeon saying the burns were one of the worst cases he had ever seen. McDonald's served coffee up to 190¬∞F (88¬∞C), a fact that they admitted was hazardous and had led to over 700 customers complaining about coffee burns. She asked for McDonald's to cover her 20,000 $USD medical expenses, but after six months, they only offered $800. After trying to settle, she eventually took them to court. After they were taken to court, McDonald's settled and agreed to lower their coffee temperatures. Then McDonald's lawyers tried to convince Americans that there was an "epidemic of frivolous lawsuits" to vilify her. Even now, large corporations sponsor groups to criticize frivolous lawsuits.

Balenciaga apologized twice and temporarily suspended the management staff during an investigation.
Keurig's K-Cups have been criticized for their impact on the environment, as they aren't biodegradable and produce lots of waste.

Workers went on strike after Keurig Dr Pepper proposed large cuts to employee benefits, including a $1.50USD/hr wage cut for all employees. The strike lasted for almost 4 months and, after pressure from several politicians and organizations, ended with a new agreement without wage cuts or pension eliminations.
Panera paid 5 million $USD to settle two class-action lawsuits against it due to labor issues such as not providing overtime pay and break periods to employees.
A class-action lawsuit was filed against Panera as workers claimed they were not paid overtime wages.
Ancestors of JAB's current owners were literal Nazis who used slave labor and forced female workers to work naked under threat of sexual assault.
In 2010, workers protested plans to shut down a Hugo Boss plant in Brooklyn. After their protests succeeded, Hugo Boss tried to shut down the plant again in 2015, once again resulting in protests.

Hugo Boss was fined 1.2 million ¬£GBP after a 120kg mirror in one of their outlet stores fell on a four year old boy, causing irreversible brain damage that eventually killed him. The Oxford Crown Court found that the mirror had been "negligently left free-standing."
After a brewery filed for a trademark of its "Boss Brewing" name, Hugo Boss sent a cease and desist, leading to 10,000 ¬£GBP in legal fees for the small brewery.

Lacoste ran a photography competition which included Palestinian artist Larissa Sansour's work as one of the 8 nominees. A month before the winner was decided, Sansour was informed that her work was not appropriate for the competition, as it was "too pro-Palestinian."

Pret employees are required to perform "Pret Behaviours" such as "creating a sense of fun" and "being happy to be themselves," and one worker was fired after trying to start a union because being "unhappy enough to want to start a union" was at odds with the company's forced happiness policy.
Pret a Manger fired an employee for organizing a union demanding a living wage.
Multiple people have died from allergy-related deaths due to Pret's failure to properly label allergens in their foods.
Greenpeace UK launched a campaign tying Essity is involved in the destruction of the Great Northern Forest spanning from Canada to Russia.
Colgate-Palmolive was listed as one of the top ten global plastic polluters in the world by BreakFreeFromPlastic.
Colgate-Palmolive was one of hundreds of companies held responsible for hazardous waste that contributed to the contamination of almost 15,000 cubic meters of soil.
A class action lawsuit was filed against Hill's after some of their food contained potentially toxic levels of vitamin D, which led to some dogs dying prematurely.

After a California Proposition passed that defined app-based drivers as independent contractors and not employees, stores owned by Albertson's in California fired their delivery drivers, outsourcing their deliveries to contractors.
